bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 6, 1941

div1.p: Kean points out misinformation written in an article about Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 6, 1941
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
2.30 p.m
June 6, 1941
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
I have just received and
read, with great pleasure your
admirable address at Cleveland
on the unveiling of Mr. Cornwell's
painting the Conquerors of yellow
fever. Mrs. Blossom Reed told
me - with great enthusiasm over
the phone of her wonderful trip and
experience at Cleveland. General
Ireland was also much pleased
to be there. It was fine also for
you to get to know Col. Siler, who
is of the salt of the earth. Mrs Blossom
Reed sent me a copy of the Plain
Dealer of June 3 which published on
AC
K
2
page 7 an alleged interview with
Kissinger; the most astonishing pot
pourri of mis-statements which I
have ever seen brought together to-
gether in so short a space. It would be
curious to know just how many of them
Kissinger is responsible and how many
should be charged up to the heedless
scorn of the facts in the case, of the
common garden variety of Cub reporter:

1. “It was just 40 years ago this month that I was inoculated
2. I was sick for 3 years afterward.
3. For 3 days, we lived in a small room heated
to a tropical temperature. We slept on pillows
& sheets soiled with blood and vomitus &c
4 We were then moved to another build-
ing ..&. exposed our bodies to the bites of
loaded mosquitoes. Within an hour
we had developed yellow fever. The
5 faith Maj. Reed had placed in the theory
of a kindly old Havana physician Dr Aristides
Agramonte had been justified.”

If we divide the honors between them
50-50 it shows that both were of the
ancient family of Anacias.
Do you know I do not believe that
Kissinger's myelitis, a decade or more
after his discharge from the army
on the expiration of his term of enlistment,
had the slightest connection with yellow
fever. It was, I have understood, prompt-
ly cured under appropriate treatment.

I am embarrassed at being in the group
of heroes - and am no less surprised.
If I am asked about it I can only
say that is it is an act of artistic
licence for which I am not in any
way responsible.

I did not give you the framed
contract of Walter Reed with Benigno
when you were here because I wanted
to ask Mrs Kean if she wanted to
keep it. She said at once that you
4
were the one person in the world
who should have it and asked me
to tell you so with her compliments
It will be a little awkward to
ship framed so I think I will take
it out, and send it in a roll to
you - unless you wish some other dispo-
sition to be made of it.

I am feeling all right again
now, gratias adios

closer.seg:
I did not see Mrs Francks bill
but know she put in a whole Sunday
at the typewriter so I hope it
was satisfactory.
